xUnit is based on the idea that tests should:

* execute automatically
* be=
 self-verifying
* be easy to compose into ever-larger collections to execut=
e as a group

I believe in doing manual testing to learn about object behav=
ior and automated testing to leverage that learning and "avoid forgetting".=
 If you simply take your manual verification and put it into a running test=
, you'll have the best of both worlds: use the inspector to learn what the =
answer should be, then code a test that includes that fact. Henceforth, you=
 can run that new test and never forget what you learned in the inspector.
=

The xUnit practitioner's approach revolves around writing the self-verifyi=
ng test in the first place. I think we need to remember that manual testing=
 continues to be useful as a learning technique. James Bach and company hel=
ped us rediscover that at XP/Agile Universe 2002.

I did not try to change =
your point of view. I gave you an opportunity to understand ours so that yo=
u can make a more informed choice. Frankly, I don't care whether you use in=
spectors, write xUnit tests or use a divining rod to write software. That's=
 your choice.

There is certainly no need for you to be antagonistic about =
it.

Take care.
